p: A high prevalence of seropositive rodents in the USA and Asia[ 14– 18] provides strong evidence that rodents could be potential reservoirs of HEV [ 14, 16, 17]. Recently, in Europe and Asia, in several small rodent and insectivore species HEV RNA Orthohepevirus C genotype was also detected [ 19– 22]. However, studies conducted on rodents, other than rats, are lacking, so the evaluation of rodents as competent reservoirs of HEV-3 still remains uncertain even though HEV-1 and HEV-3 have experimentally been derived from human liver chimeric mice [ 23]. Moreover, a successful infection of Mus musculus mouse liver cell culture with HEV-3, supports the hypothesis that rodents may be competent hosts [ 24].
